dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, today we're diving into Bitcoin, and honestly, it's such a wild ride. Like, when you think about it, it's this unique money that isn't controlled by any central bank.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, today we're diving into Bitcoin, and honestly, it's such a wild ride. Like, when you think about it, it's this unique money that isn't controlled by any central bank.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bitcoin is a unique monetary asset in that it is free from the control of any central bank and doesnt need to be audited by a third party to ensure its value.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's pretty mind-blowing, right? And it doesn't need, uh, anyone to audit its value. Instead, you've got thousands of computers tracking and verifying everything on this shared network.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's pretty mind-blowing, right? And it doesn't need, uh, anyone to audit its value. Instead, you've got thousands of computers tracking and verifying everything on this shared network.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is instead tracked and verified by thousands of computers on a shared network that is called a blockchain, which uses cryptography to reach consensus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's the blockchain! Which, um, uses cryptography to keep everything secure. And the potential of this underlying tech, like, it's not just about finance anymore.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the blockchain! Which, um, uses cryptography to keep everything secure. And the potential of this underlying tech, like, it's not just about finance anymore.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bitcoins underlying distributed ledger technology has the potential to not only dramatically overhaul finance, but also fields ranging from property ownership to health care and voting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It could overhaul everything from property ownership to healthcare. It's huge. And to think, just over a decade ago, barely anyone knew what Bitcoin was.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. It could overhaul everything from property ownership to healthcare. It's huge. And to think, just over a decade ago, barely anyone knew what Bitcoin was.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As the decade began, only a handful knew anything about bitcoin, which was created on January 3, 2009 by a mysterious developer known to the world as Satoshi Nakamoto.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Created on January 3, 2009, by a mysterious developer known as Satoshi Nakamoto. And get this: in the very first block of code, he actually embedded a newspaper headline.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Created on January three, two thousand nine, by a mysterious developer known as Satoshi Nakamoto. And get this: in the very first block of code, he actually embedded a newspaper headline.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Buried within the code of his Genesis block, Nakamoto embedded a reminder of what happens when too much trust is placed in banks. It was a headline from a British newspaper...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, the one about the banks getting bailed out after 2008? "Chancellor On Brink of Second Bailout for Banks." That's such a perfect, um, symbolic kick-off.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, the one about the banks getting bailed out after two thousand eight? "Chancellor On Brink of Second Bailout for Banks." That's such a perfect, um, symbolic kick-off.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Times 03/Jan/2009 Chancellor On Brink of Second Bailout for Banks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! A clear message about trusting banks too much. And in 2010, the first full decade of digital currency without banks really started, with that block that rewarded 100 Bitcoin.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! A clear message about trusting banks too much. And in twenty ten, the first full decade of digital currency without banks really started, with that block that rewarded one hundred Bitcoin.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The first full decade of digital currency without banks kicked off a year later, on January 1, 2010, with the mining of bitcoin block number 32620, which rewarded its miner with 50 bitcoin...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which, at the time, was worth less than a penny, but now it's, what, like, half a million dollars? Wild. For years it was just for programmers and libertarians, though.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, at the time, was worth less than a penny, but now it's, what, like, half a million dollars? Wild. For years it was just for programmers and libertarians, though.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...which rewarded its miner with 50 bitcoin, then worth less than a single penny but now worth about $375,000. For the first five years or so, bitcoin largely went unnoticed, appealing to a fringe group of programmers and libertarian idealists.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it went largely unnoticed. But then, as people started getting their heads around blockchain technology, that's when, you know, Bitcoin and other crypto speculation just took off.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it went largely unnoticed. But then, as people started getting their heads around blockchain technology, that's when, you know, Bitcoin and other crypto speculation just took off.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: During the latter half of the decade, as more people came to understand the benefits of blockchain technology, bitcoin and other cryptocurrency speculation took off.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But it hasn't been smooth sailing, has it? I mean, we've had some pretty infamous scandals.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it hasn't been smooth sailing, has it? I mean, we've had some pretty infamous scandals.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] Oh, definitely. Like the FBI shutting down Silk Road, that underground drug marketplace, back in 2013. And then the Mt. Gox hack the next year, four hundred fifty million dollars stolen!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, definitely. Like the F B I shutting down Silk Road, that underground drug marketplace, back in twenty thirteen. And then the Mt. Gox hack the next year, four hundred fifty million dollars stolen!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The nascent technology has been plagued by infamous scandals like the FBIs shuttering of underground bitcoin-fueled drug and contraband marketplace Silk Road in 2013 and the $450 million hacking of cryptocurrency exchange Mt. Gox in 2014.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Unbelievable. And that 2017 frenzy? I remember that, Bitcoin hitting twenty thousand dollars.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unbelievable. And that twenty seventeen frenzy? I remember that, Bitcoin hitting twenty thousand dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the end of 2017, the frenzy in cryptocurrency speculation peaked with bitcoin at $20,000...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pure madness. Produced thousands of worthless tokens and billions in investor losses. But you know what's really fascinating?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pure madness. Produced thousands of worthless tokens and billions in investor losses. But you know what's really fascinating?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...and produced thousands of worthless cryptocurrency tokens and investor losses in the billions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: The very companies that early Bitcoin believers were rallying against – like JPMorgan, IBM – they're now some of the most enthusiastic supporters and co-opters of blockchain technology.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The very companies that early Bitcoin believers were rallying against - like J P Morgan, I B M - they're now some of the most enthusiastic supporters and co-opters of blockchain technology.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In fact in a bit cruel irony, some of the most enthusiastic supporters and co-opters of blockchain technology today are those same big companies, ranging from IBM and Cargill to JPMorgan, that early bitcoin believers were rallying against.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That is, uh, such a cruel irony, but also kind of amazing. Like, the tech is so powerful, even the old guard can't ignore it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That is, uh, such a cruel irony, but also kind of amazing. Like, the tech is so powerful, even the old guard can't ignore it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. It’s changing how banks, corporations, and even governments operate. It’s just getting started.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. It's changing how banks, corporations, and even governments operate. It's just getting started.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A budding ecosystem has arisen, powered by new computer languages and breakthroughs in cryptography that is only now starting to change the way banks, corporations and governments operate.
